fields.description:
During key generation node controller tries to copy certificate files like /etc/pki/CA/cacert.pem, which are all blocked by SELinux.

fields.summary: Migrate instance failed due to generate-migration-keys.sh restart failure when SELinux is enabled

comments.body:
We're using libvirtd's [default locations|https://libvirt.org/remote.html#Remote_PKI] for X.509 credentials, which are the following:

* /etc/pki/CA/cacert.pem
* /etc/pki/libvirt/private/serverkey.pem
* /etc/pki/libvirt/servercert.pem
* /etc/pki/libvirt/private/clientkey.pem
* /etc/pki/libvirt/clientcert.pem

It's really dangerous for a daemon to write to /etc/pki, especially one running on a box with untrusted workloads.  Even worse, basically everything in /etc/pki is labelled {{cert_t}}, so we can't restrict eucalyptus and libvirtd to only a subset of that, either.

Before the eucalyptus-node service runs we run generate-migration-keys.sh separately.  If we can limit writes to /etc/pki to that specific invocation then this problem should go away.
Let's investigate if these specific certs have to be generated for each migration or not.

After looking through the code there is migration credentials sent for each so it appears there is migration specific entropy used in their generation.

According to this:
http://libvirt.org/remote.html#Remote_PKI

We can trying generating them in $HOME/.pki/libvirt instead. It's not clear if that $HOME is in context to the running libvirtd daemon or the process establishing the connection. This value is hardcoded in the bash script so we could try it fairly simply.

Further discussion is needed to determine when this should be implemented.

Likely candidate solution is as follows:
# At NC startup generate server keys and install them
## Check on subsequent restarts for presence rather than just brute force repeating prior step
# At migration time generate client certs and install to alternate path
## According to the documentation pkipath can be appended to the connection string/uri to find client certificates
## According to the documentation $HOME/.pki/libvirt will also be searched w/o specifying for client certificates before searching global default
# At migration time modify tls_allowed_dn_list and restart libvirt daemon

There is already a eucalyptus-node-keygen.service and the sysv init scripts call the script to generate the server keys.

The existing script should be modified to only generate client keys if the server cert is present otherwise attempt both.

Updated script for key generation and init scripts to use new workflow.

This should require no new permissions and uses cert/key path search locations from libvirt source.


For reference
http://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=blob;f=src/rpc/virnettlscontext.c;hb=HEAD#l776
I am concerned about ownership of /etc/pki/libvirt/private, but as that is a preexisting problem I will file a new bug for that.

On a freshly builded system in QA http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/4370/artifact/machine_list/*view*/ migration does not work. [~jbreiding], should the fix be reverted?

[~vasya] I think for this release adding the permissions so this works in SELinux policy is the best option.

This is back on the subject of what discussed about removing this functionality from the NC process completely.
Let's allow this in the policy for 4.3.0 and then fix the cause in 4.3.1.

I am seeing issue when trying to migrate an instance and following occurs when generating keys:

{noformat}
# ausearch -m avc --start recent
----
time->Tue Jun 28 13:08:26 2016
type=SYSCALL msg=audit(1467144506.982:5541): arch=c000003e syscall=268 success=no exit=-13 a0=ffffffffffffff9c a1=94e0f0 a2=1c0 a3=7ffd9f784de0 items=0 ppid=31065 pid=31066 auid=4294967295 uid=0 gid=0 euid=0 suid=0 fsuid=0 egid=0 sgid=0 fsgid=0 tty=(none) ses=4294967295 comm="chmod" exe="/usr/bin/chmod" subj=system_u:system_r:eucalyptus_node_t:s0 key=(null)
